In an optics experiment, students are given a laser light source, eye protection, and a glass block <math alttext="n equals 1.50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.50</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> . The students want to find the critical angle (angle of incidence above which total internal reflection occurs) at the glass-air boundary. They adjust the angle of incidence <math alttext="theta sub i" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the laser beam in the glass and record the angle of refraction <math alttext="theta sub r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in air, as shown in the figure.
